div.head: Title
div.p: Ruskin wrote the title as “The defiance of war”; he also designated the poem as “poem III” in “Poetry” [MS I Poetry Anthology]. See System of Title Citation for Works.

div.head: Manuscripts
div.p: MS I (pp. 101–2), a Red Book devoted primarily to “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 1”. “The Defiance of War” is the second poem in the “Poetry” [MS I Poetry Anthology].
Facsimiles by permission of John Ruskin Collection, General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Transcriptions of texts and commentary © David C. Hanson.

div.head: Date
div.p: September 1826–January 1827, most likely toward the end of that period. There is a possibility of the poem dating from as early as January 1826; see “The Needless Alarm”: Date.

This poem, with its exhortation to guard “our peaceful home” from suffering and death, could allude to the removal of Ruskinʼs dying cousin, James Richardson, from Herne Hill in April 1826. If so, the poem might have been composed, or at least refer to a period, earlier than January 1827 (see Discussion; “On Scotland”; and “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol. 2”).

div.head: Composition and Publication
div.p: Hand is pencil, print; see The Ruskin Family Handwriting.

div.head: Pacifism in the 1820s
div.p: In London in 1816, at the end of the Napoleonic Wars, the Peace Society was founded as a coalition of Quakers and other Dissenters, such as Congregationalists--the Ruskins' church at this time--Baptists, and of course the rationalist and progressive Unitarians, as well as Anglican Evangelicals. Peter Brock characterizes the society as marking the emergence of an organized peace movement as compared with earlier, sporadic assertions of Christian pacifism by individuals, and as partaking of the reform optimism of the 1820s-30s generally. A middle-class movement, and never a broadly populist one, the society was intent initially on converting British opinion through pamphleteering. As the flush of optimism surrounding the Vienna Settlement gave way to rising nationalism and contests between reactionary state policies and republican movements, the Peace Society advocated nonintervention. It finally found a political platform through alliance with free-trade internationalists (Brock, Pacifism in Europe, 376-86).

The latest credible threat of invasion of British shores had ended, of course, in 1815 with the Battle of Waterloo, which closed the Napoleonic Wars. In late 1826, an international incident that had the potential to affect trade occurred in the East, in connection with the Greek War for Independence from Turkish domination. While no threat to Britain, the war would have interested the Ruskins for its associations with Lord Byron, who had died in Missolonghi in 1824. In the Greek conflict, Britain was striving to avoid an outbreak between Turkey and Russia, whose new tsar, Nicholas I, was willing to push hostilities. In October 1826, Britain pressured Turkey to accept Russian conditions in the Convention of Akkerman. This assured Russian influence in the Caucasus and the opening of the Straits of Bosphorus to trade, which might have interested the Ruskinsʼ mercantile household. As it turned out, Russia continued to press hostilities in the name of the Greek cause, and Britain joined France and Russia to declare joint mediation, according to a treaty signed in London in July 1827. (In the subsequent history, the Turks refused mediation but were defeated by allied fleets at Navarino in October 1827. The Treaty of Adrianople, rendering Greece autonomous, was signed two years later, in September 1829.)

div.head: Pacifism and Domesticity
div.p: While Ruskin may have heard his parents discusss these international affairs or listened to a clergyman defend the Christian ethics of pacifism, that the sentiment of his anti-war message is centered in protection of the home suggests the influence of poems and tales composed mainly by women in opposition to war and the military. One likely source of exposure to such writing was Evenings at Home by the Unitarian educationalists, Mrs. Barbauld and her brother John Aikin, although it is impossible to specify when and with what extent of supervision Ruskin dipped into this miscellaneous "juvenile budget" of dialogues, fables, and poems, enabling him to discover its anti-war pieces. In "Things by Their Right Names", a dialogue that has been credited to Barbauld's authorship rather than her brother's, a Father obliges the wish of his son Charles for a story about "bloody murder"; however, in place of the various props and characters of romance, the Father substitutes unexpected "right names" for these elements of the story. As Charles pieces together these words, he realizes the Father is not relating a thriller but describing a battle: "'I do not know any murders half so bloody'", the Father concludes. The threat to home is implicit, as the family is gathered "'round the fire quite ready to hear'" a good story, only to find their expectations invaded by disturbing realities of violence (Barbauld and Aikin, Evenings at Home, 1:154-56).

Other anti-war dialogues and tales in Evenings at Home, probably by Aikin or perhaps collaborations by Aikin and Barbauld, include the dramatic sketch "The Two Robbers", which uses a similar strategy of substituting "right" definitions, as a captured Thracian dresses down Alexander the Great from the status of war "hero" by exposing the conqueror's actions as those a "robber" no better than the Thracian himself (2:152-56). In the dialogue "The Price of a Victory", a boy enters "his father's house" proclaiming the "glorious news" of "a complete victory", only to hear his father unpack the news by rationally weighing the illusory benefits of the victory against its hugely painful costs. The father illustrates his point with the story of a soldier who returns home from battle grotesquely wounded, and whose death causes the decline of his fiance and parents (4:52-63).

Barbauld and Aikin's anti-war rhetoric in Evenings in Home is consistent with radical discourse that was shared among reformers during the Revolutionary period. The language is simpler and the ironies less biting than in Barbauld's political pamphlets, but the fact that she adapted such arguments to less sophisticated readers would have rendered the writing, with only a slight shift in circumstances at the height of the government's alarm in the 1790s, all the more subject to prosecution for sedition (Trethewey, "Lady Defender of the Revolution", 163-65, 161). Moreover, since Barbauld's mastery of shared radical discourse rendered her political writing indistinguishable from that of men, she was accused in her own time of becoming "unsexed", and over the course of the century she came to be viewed as a humorless bore (Mahon, "Sermon and Story", 29-30; McCarthy, "'A High-Minded Christian Lady'", 179-80).

But while the case against war was available to Ruskin in Evenings at Home, his poem reflects little, if any, of the rational and religious discourse that was held in common by liberals and pacifists. The poem, rather, is anti-war without being anti-militarist. Perhaps a common pacifist contention that only the ruling class benefits by war can be glimpsed in the comment that war "like[s] better a king to be", but overwhelmingly the pacifist message is delivered with discordantly belligerent threats that any invading army "here shall suffering die". The gender positioning seems aggressively masculine, with the promise that war will in its turn be conquered by "he" who is "the strongest of us"--the patriarch of the household, presumably, or a military hero of the nation. This aspect of the poem may be predictable for a youth whose imagination was keenly captured by Waterloo, as expressed throughout the late 1820s in works such as “The British Battles”, “Battle of Waterloo: A Play in Two Acts”, “Ballad on Waterloo”, and “Trafalgar”. Just so, Charlotte and Branwell Brontë made Wellington the hero of their sagas, but Ruskinʼs fascination with the Battle of Waterloo was not drawn just from books. A year earlier than compiling the “Poetry” [MS I Poetry Anthology], during the Tour of 1825 to the Continent, the Ruskins visited Waterloo Field.

For all its contradictions, Ruskin's "The Defiance of War" seems akin to women's poetry of the period that defied war more by celebrating the endurance of domestic peace than by arguing against the legitimacy of conflict--or that at least obscured their critiques of war by using medieval settings or other distancing effects (see Saunders, "Louisa Stuart Costello and Women's War Poetry"). For example, according to Felicia Hemans's "The Domestic Affections", published in 1812 when the Napoleonic Wars still raged, home is an "ark of refuge" and a "fane of rest [that] no raging storms invade" (lines 76, 61). The poem asks rhetorically whether "war's dread scenes [can] the hallow'd ties efface" and whether "fields of carnage, days of toil, [can] destroy / The lov'd impressions of domestic joy?" (lines 111-14). Triumphantly, the poem asserts the "mystic power" of domestic affections (line 252) to overcome these and even stranger trials as well as to outlast competing but ephemeral sources of joy such as fame and genius. Doubt emerges only when evocation of "maternal love" prompts the question of "who may charm her sleepless pang to rest" (lines 341, 343) (Hemans, Selected Poems, ed. Wolfson, 4-15).

Women writers did not have to share Barbauld's politics to feel anxiety about the threat of war to the British home. As Linda Colley remarks, during the Revolutionary and Napoleonic Era, “many women . . . seem to have believed that their own security and the security of the family unit were at stake in this French war as they had not been in earlier conflicts. In part, this was because the risk of a French invasion of Britain was so much greater in this war than ever before. But crucial, too, as an ingredient in female anxiety was the destruction of Marie‐Antoinette and the rest of the French Royal Family”—a regicide that Edmund Burkeʼs Reflections on the Revolution in France (1790) taught the elder Ruskinsʼ generation to stigmatize specifically in terms “of a queen who was also a wife and mother being driven by force from her home” (Colley, Britons, 254, 253).
